title: Pay to License, or Build to Liberate?
context:
Bill Gates urges hobbyists to pay for software. Currently, your lab use UNIX, a proprietary operating system.However, as you are expanding your research scope, you worry about the financial burden of paying for an increasing number of proprietary software. 
What will you do next?
choice-success: Start to program an operating system from scratch.
choice-end-outcome: Your lab continued with proprietary UNIX. Eventually, you couldn’t bear the financial burden and had to shut down. ☹️
choice-success-outcome: Your lab initiated a collaboration with other institutions on operating system development. You share code with each other, and the community is growing.

title: Defend Open Source or Stay Neutral?
context:
Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer has made a controversial statement, calling Linux a 'cancer' due to its viral open-source license. The remark has stirred strong reactions across the software community. As a developer and community member, you feel the weight of this moment. 
How will you respond?
choice-end: Stay silent and continue using proprietary tools.
choice-success: Join the free software movement and advocate for Linux.
choice-end-outcome: You chose to stay out of the conflict. While the storm passed, your team gradually fell behind as open tools gained traction in other labs. Momentum was lost.
choice-success-outcome: You spoke out, joined the open-source movement, and hosted local meetups on software freedom. Your lab adopted Linux and became a regional hub for open-source innovation.
